name: jute production, rainfed | jute plant, harvested | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19444/documentation

Jute farming activity in Bangladesh starts right after the harvest of the previous non-jute crops in the field. Jute farming covers soil preparation (fall tillage), inputs of seeds, application of mineral fertilizers, jute plant  harvesting. The soil is prepared for the jute cultivation through fall plough by using auto-tiller machine in March-April. Then the seeds are sown. Mineral fertilizers are applied during the growth period. Usually jute cultivation does not involve heavy use of pesticides. Jute is generally harvested when the plants are at early pod stage. The harvest index remains more or less constant over 60â€“105 day period following sowing. The yield is 2680 kg/ha.The inventory is modelled for fresh matter.;The dataset represents the production of 1 kg of jute plant in Bangladesh in 2017. The activity covers soil preparation (fall tillage), inputs of seeds, mineral fertilizers, harvesting. Machinery and fixed overhead are excluded.;In Bangladesh, it is the time when rainy season starts. That's why irrigation is usually not required for jute cultivation. Accordingly, we considered the jute arming activity as a rainfed agronomic practice. Machinery and fixed overhead are excluded from life cycle inventory for the activity as their impacts per kg of jute plant is very low since the machineries and fixed overheads provide services over several years.;This dataset covers only the field activities for the production of jute. That means the technical boundary ends at the harvesting of the mature jute plant. The mature plant is not dried. The harvested plant goes to the jute retting process where transformation of raw jute from the jute plan happens. The retting process is covered in a separate dataset.

This activity starts right after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for the jute cultivation.

The activity ends at the harvesting of the mature jute plant.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0116:Growing of fibre crops

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Cultivation of Jute from conventional production standards
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The data on inputs to the field activites are collected directly from the farmers and farming experts. However, the emission data were not readily available for Bangladesh. Hence,  the ecoinvent LCI calculation tool for crop production was used to calculate field emissions from the cultivation process. However, again, Quantis had to use geography India as a proxy to Bangladesh.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Focus group discussion, expert interviews, literature data and assumptions. Data collection started off with the existing literature data survey. Bangladesh Yearbook of Agricultural Statistics documents the production statistics of jute goods. Bangladesh Agricultural Information Service describes a standard agricultural practice for the jute cultivation in Bangladesh. The literature data were supported by a total of three focus group discussions among the jute farmers and agricultural extension officers of jute growing areas in Bangladesh. Standardized questionnaires were developed and adapted to jute-specific cultivation and post-harvest situation. The secondary data from literature and the primary data from surveys were compared and matched to obtain highest data quality. The collected data on inputs to the field activities are then used to calculate impacts by using the Agriculture Life Cycle Inventory Generator tool from Quantis International.

exchanges.description: The output of the jute cultivation activity. Mature jute plant is harvested.

flow.name: Transformation, from arable land, unspecified use

exchanges.description:
Due to lack o data related to land use change of annual crops in Bangladesh, this exchange is added to cover the impact of LUC, using the methodology applied in Global datasets. 
Global average LUC emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The emission are based on the relative change in production areas in all countries for a given crop. The weighted average is used which takes into acount relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land. The amount of 110  kg of CO2 per ha*year (taken from the tool) is divided with the yield of jute plant, harvested, 2680 kg/ha.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'jute plant, harvested' is calculated to be circa 4.01E-02 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'potassium chloride, as K2O', 'urea, as N'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 8.02E-02 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.
